	This is somewhat off topic, but when I tried doing this I got errors
from=
 Eclipse about duplicate files. The problem is my Visual Source Safe
files =
that are left in every directory, and always named the same. Is it
possible=
 to to get Eclipse to ignore duplicate files?

	Also, when you specify mult=
iple input directories like this, doesn't
bunch all of your class files fro=
m the various directory structures
together? I tend to like to keep my clas=
s files in the same directories as
their respective java files, but that's =
just me...

	-tim

Bill de h=D3ra asked:
> Has anyone had any success getting =
Eclipse to understand a project 
> whose junit code is organized as follows=
:
> 
>    src/
>        java/
>             a/b/c
>        test/
>         =
    a/b/c

Yes, I've got something similar.  My organization is actually as=
 follows

	project/
		classes/
		source/
			com/...
		test/
			com/...

In =
the Resource Perspective, rightclick on the project in the Navigator tree
a=
nd select Properties.  Select "Java Build Path" on the left and the
"Source=
" tab on the right.  Set the radio button for "Use source folders
contained=
 in the project" and either add or create your source and test
folders.

It=
 works for me, but ask away if this doesn't work or doesn't make sense.

 -=
 George
